factoid: The gentlemen assembled at Bilíbin's were young, wealthy, gay society men.
The gentlemen assembled at Bilíbin's formed a special set called les nôtres.
Bilíbin was the leader of the set les nôtres.
The set les nôtres consisted almost exclusively of diplomats.
The set les nôtres had interests unrelated to war or politics, related to high society, certain women, and the official side of the service.
The gentlemen received Prince Andrew as one of themselves, an honor they did not extend to many.
The gentlemen asked Prince Andrew a few questions about the army and the battle.
The talk with Prince Andrew went off into merry jests and gossip.
One of the gentlemen said that the best of it was the misfortune of a fellow diplomat.
The Chancellor told the fellow diplomat flatly that his appointment to London was a promotion.
The fellow diplomat was told to regard his appointment to London as a promotion.
One of the gentlemen said that the worst of it was that a man suffers and Don Juan is taking advantage of it.
Prince Hippolyte was lolling in a lounge chair with his legs over its arm.
Prince Hippolyte began to laugh.
Prince Hippolyte said, "Tell me about that!"
Several voices cried, "Oh, you Don Juan! You serpent!"
Bilíbin turned to Prince Andrew and said that all the atrocities of the French army are nothing compared to what Don Juan has been doing among the women.
Prince Hippolyte announced, "La femme est la compagne de l’homme."
Prince Hippolyte began looking through a lorgnette at his elevated legs.
Bilíbin and the rest of "ours" burst out laughing at Prince Hippolyte.
Prince Andrew saw that Prince Hippolyte was the butt of this set.
Prince Andrew had almost been jealous of Prince Hippolyte because of his wife.
Bilíbin whispered to Bolkónski that Kurágin is exquisite when he discusses politics.
Bilíbin suggested that Bolkónski should see Kurágin's gravity.
Bilíbin sat down beside Prince Hippolyte and talked to him about politics.
Prince Andrew and the others gathered around Bilíbin and Prince Hippolyte.
Hippolyte began that the Berlin cabinet cannot express a feeling of alliance without expressing something.
Hippolyte said that unless His Majesty the Emperor derogates from the principle of our alliance, he has not finished.
Hippolyte said that intervention will be stronger than nonintervention.
Hippolyte said that one cannot impute the nonreceipt of our dispatch of November 18.
Hippolyte said that this is how it will end.
Bilíbin said, "Demosthenes, I know thee by the pebble thou secretest in thy golden mouth!"
Bilíbin's mop of hair moved with satisfaction.
Everybody laughed.
Prince Hippolyte laughed louder than anyone.
Prince Hippolyte was distressed and breathed painfully.
Prince Hippolyte could not restrain the wild laughter that convulsed his usually impassive features.
Bilíbin said that Bolkónski is his guest in this house and in Brünn.
Bilíbin wanted to entertain Bolkónski with all the pleasures of life in Brünn.
Bilíbin said that if they were in Vienna it would be easy, but in Brünn it is more difficult.
Bilíbin begged everyone to help him entertain Bolkónski.
Bilíbin said that Brünn's attractions must be shown to Bolkónski.
Bilíbin said that the audience can undertake the theater, society, and Prince Hippolyte can take care of the women.
One of "ours" said that they must let Bolkónski see Amelie and that she is exquisite.
Bilíbin said that they must turn this bloodthirsty soldier to more humane interests.
Prince Andrew replied that he shall scarcely be able to avail himself of hospitality and it is already time for him to go.
Prince Andrew looked at his watch.
Prince Andrew asked where to.
Bilíbin answered "To the Emperor."
Bilíbin exclaimed "Oh! Oh! Oh!"
